speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks what the noise is about, showing her initial confusion upon entering the scene.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She repeats her question about what is happening, growing more alarmed by the Nurse's distress.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She cries out in grief, urging Juliet to wake up or else she will die too, and calls for help.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He impatiently calls for Juliet to be brought out, unaware she is dead and thinking Paris has arrived.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She echoes the Nurse's cry, lamenting repeatedly that Juliet is dead.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He examines Juliet and confirms she is cold and stiff, using a metaphor of frost killing a flower to express how death has taken her too soon.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She exclaims again in sorrow, calling the time woeful.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He says grief has stolen his ability to speak, personifying Death as silencing him.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He arrives and asks if the bride is ready for the wedding, unaware of the situation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He bitterly replies that she is ready but will not return, saying Death has lain with and deflowered her, making Death his heir and son-in-law.

speaker: PARIS
content: He expresses his shock and disappointment, having looked forward to his wedding morning only to find tragedy.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She curses the day as miserable and accursed, lamenting that cruel death has taken her only source of joy and solace.

speaker: PARIS
content: He feels deceived and wronged by death, crying out that what remains is not life but love in death.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He lists his sufferings and asks why this unhappy time has ruined the wedding, saying his joys are buried with his child.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He scolds them for their excessive grief, arguing that Juliet is now in heaven and they should rejoice she died pure and young. He tells them to dry their tears, adorn her body with rosemary, and carry her to church as custom dictates.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He observes how all their wedding preparations have turned into funeral arrangements: instruments become bells, cheer becomes a burial feast, hymns become dirges, and flowers adorn a corpse.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He instructs everyone to follow Juliet's body to the grave, warning that the heavens frown upon them for some wrong and they should not oppose divine will by further mourning. This provides solemn closure to the mourning scene and clears the stage for the comic relief that follows.

speaker: PETER
content: He urgently asks the musicians to play 'Heart's ease,' a cheerful tune, saying it's necessary for his survival since his heart is heavy with sorrow.

speaker: PETER
content: He explains he wants a merry dump—a contradiction since 'dump' meant a sad song—to comfort him, showing his confused emotional state.

speaker: PETER
content: He bluntly confirms their refusal to play.

speaker: PETER
content: He threatens to punish them soundly for their refusal.

speaker: PETER
content: He clarifies he won't pay money but will give them the gleek—a jest or trick—and call them minstrels insultingly.

speaker: PETER
content: He escalates his threat, saying he'll hit them with a dagger and won't tolerate their crotchets (whims or quarter-notes in music). He puns on musical notes 're' and 'fa,' meaning he'll attack them.

speaker: PETER
content: He sheathes his dagger and promises to outwit them instead, quoting a ballad about music soothing grief, then questioning why it calls music's sound 'silver.'

speaker: PETER
content: He dismisses the first musician's answer as prates (idle talk) and asks another for his explanation.

speaker: PETER
content: He similarly rejects the second musician's answer and questions the third, who admits he doesn't know.

speaker: PETER
content: He sarcastically excuses the third musician for being a singer rather than a thinker, then offers his own punchline: musicians have no gold, only silver, for their playing. He completes the quoted verse to mock their mercenary motives.
